<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 170, 250]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 211, 905, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 232, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/42  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 245, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Mechanics  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 395, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 270, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 808, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 513]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 514, 359, 528]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 529, 868, 560]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 605]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 856, 636]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 636, 777, 652]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity \((g)\) is needed, use \(10 \text{m} \text{s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 213, 695]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 696, 729, 728]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50. The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 72, 106, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 88, 870, 333]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 920, 445]]<|/det|>
The velocity of a particle moving in a straight line at time \(t\) seconds after leaving a fixed point \(O\) is \(\nu \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) . The diagram shows a velocity-time graph which models the motion of the particle from \(t = 0\) to \(t = T\) . The graph consists of four straight line segments. The particle accelerates from rest to a speed of \(V \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) over a period of \(4 \mathrm{s}\), and then decelerates at \(\frac{5}{3} \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 2}\) to instantaneous rest over a period of \(6 \mathrm{s}\). The particle then travels back towards \(O\), reaching a maximum speed of \(3 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\) before coming to rest at time \(t = T\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 458, 144, 476]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 458, 312, 476]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 458, 918, 476]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 612, 146, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 612, 918, 647]]<|/det|>
Given that the total distance travelled by the particle from \(t = 0\) to \(t = T\) is \(68 \text{m}\), find the value of \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 628, 918, 647]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
A block of mass \(20\mathrm{kg}\) is held at rest at the top of a plane inclined at \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The block is projected with speed \(5\mathrm{m}\mathrm{s}^{-1}\) down a line of greatest slope of the plane. There is a resistance force acting on the block. As the block moves \(2\mathrm{m}\) down the plane from its point of projection, the work done against this resistance force is \(50\mathrm{J}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 641, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of the block when it has moved \(2\mathrm{m}\) down the plane.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 82, 771, 222]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 234, 920, 303]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows two particles, \(A\) and \(B\), of masses \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.1 \mathrm{kg}\) respectively. The particles are suspended below a horizontal ceiling by two strings, \(AP\) and \(BQ\), attached to fixed points \(P\) and \(Q\) on the ceiling. The particles are connected by a horizontal string, \(AB\). Angle \(APQ = 45^\circ\) and \(BQP = \theta^\circ\). Each string is light and inextensible. The particles are in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 313, 146, 331]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 313, 504, 333]]<|/det|>
Find the value of the tension in the string \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 314, 917, 333]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 562, 89]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\theta\) and the tension in the string \(BQ\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 72, 918, 89]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
Two particles, \(P\) and \(Q\), of masses \(2m \mathrm{kg}\) and \(m \mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are held at rest in the same vertical line. The heights of \(P\) and \(Q\) above horizontal ground are \(1 \mathrm{m}\) and \(2 \mathrm{m}\) respectively. \(P\) is projected vertically upwards with speed \(2 \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\) . At the same instant, \(Q\) is released from rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 133, 650, 152]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of each particle immediately before they collide.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 918, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 816, 91]]<|/det|>
It is given that immediately after the collision the downward speed of \(Q\) is \(3.5 \mathrm{~m} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 620, 122]]<|/det|>
Find the speed of \(P\) at the instant that it reaches the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 922, 107]]<|/det|>
A particle, \(P\), travels in a straight line, starting from a point \(O\) with velocity \(6 \mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) . The acceleration of \(P\) at time \(t\) s after leaving \(O\) is \(a \mathrm{m s}^{-2}\) , where

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[348, 114, 638, 139]]<|/det|>
\[a = -1.5t^{\frac{1}{2}} \qquad \text{for } 0 \leqslant t \leqslant 1,\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[348, 147, 608, 170]]<|/det|>
\[a = 1.5t^{\frac{1}{2}} - 3t^{-\frac{1}{2}} \qquad \text{for } t > 1.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 180, 144, 199]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 395, 200]]<|/det|>
Find the velocity of \(P\) at \(t = 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 181, 920, 200]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 186, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 520, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
Given that there is no change in the velocity of \(P\) when \(t = 1\), find an expression for the velocity of \(P\) for \(t > 1\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 536, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Given that the velocity of \(P\) is positive for \(t \leqslant 4\), find the total distance travelled between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 4\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 85, 920, 103]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[306, 81, 685, 333]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
Two particles, \(A\) and \(B\), of masses \(0.2 \mathrm{kg}\) and \(0.3 \mathrm{kg}\) respectively, are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string. The string passes over a small fixed smooth pulley which is attached to the bottom of a rough plane inclined at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal where \(\sin \theta = 0.6\) . Particle \(A\) lies on the plane, and particle \(B\) hangs vertically below the pulley, \(0.25 \mathrm{m}\) above horizontal ground. The string between \(A\) and the pulley is parallel to a line of greatest slope of the plane (see diagram). The coefficient of friction between \(A\) and the plane is \(1.125\) . Particle \(A\) is released from rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 454, 144, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 454, 803, 473]]<|/det|>
Find the tension in the string and the magnitude of the acceleration of the particles.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 454, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
<mark>[7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 364, 144, 381]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 364, 504, 382]]<|/det|>
When \(B\) reaches the ground, it comes to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 394, 920, 428]]<|/det|>
Find the total distance that \(A\) travels down the plane from when it is released until it comes to rest. You may assume that \(A\) does not reach the pulley. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
If you use the following page to complete the answer to any question, the question number must be clearly shown.
